intro: Magnistipula tessmannii, commonly known as the KwaZulu-Natal mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the eastern regions of South Africa. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and fleshy, berry-like fruits. The plant attaches itself to the branches of its host trees, primarily from the genus *Africanum*, and derives some of its nutrients through a specialized root system. It plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food for birds and insects, and its presence can indicate the health of its host trees. Due to habitat loss, it is considered threatened and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
